_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The EPA RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA.
Note: This summary includes additional information not included in the RMP Submit to assist Thrive Freeze Dry management, process operators, technicians, contractors plus all involved and affected employees towards safe operation. In addition, some of the detail provided within this summary was excluded from the submitted RMP as current public access to this detail could expose the facility and personnel to terrorist or criminal activity.

The covered process is subject to OSHA's PSM standard. Therefore, this RMP is written to meet the EPA Program 3 level of compliance.
The following areas are addressed in this summary:
     1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source
     2. The stationary source and regulated substances handled
     3. The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including
          administrative controls and mitigation measures
     4. The accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
     5. The five-year accident history
     6. The emergency response program
     7. Planned changes to improve safety

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Thrive Freeze Dry is committed to complying with all the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. Thrive Freeze Dry has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

Federal regulations require reporting when there is a release of

ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours. RMP / PSM regulations require Thrive Freeze Dry to investigate every incident that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release. Local health and safety code requires all releases, threatened releases, and near misses to be reported to the CUPA and CalOES. Incidents shall be recorded using the incident investigation forms to determine the root cause and prevent recurrence. 

STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
Thrive Freeze Dry is the most versatile freeze-dry company in the world. Thrive Freeze Dry facilities dry everything from bulk ingredients to enzymes and probiotics to freeze-dried meals and dog treats. This facility also has the capability to store finished goods in freezer rooms prior to shipment.
Anhydrous ammonia is utilized in chambers as part of the freeze-dry process as well as maintain blast freezer and freezer room temperatures. Process 1 is a two-stage, closed loop, mechanical refrigeration system. Anhydrous ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the Thrive Freeze Dry refrigeration system and is the only regulated substance.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
Thrive Freeze Dry has implemented the Process Safety Management (PSM) rules and regulations to prevent or minimize accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. The prevention program consists of mechanical integrity, safe operating parameters of process equipment, and training measures for personnel operating or maintaining the covered process to name a few. Additional details of the prevention program are detailed below.

 Process Safety Information
Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical and equipment information. The facility has worked to keep on file the original manufacturer OEM manuals, material of construction, equipment drawings, etc. for reference purposes and to aid in maintenance activities. New equipment data is requested through the MOC process and is part of the co

ntactors package upon installation.

 Process Hazard Analysis
Provide thorough team analysis of the Thrive Freeze Dry refrigeration system. The team analyses such scenarios as an overpressure situation, high and/or lower pressures or temperatures, corrosion, equipment failure, equipment siting, emergency situations and human factors. The types of natural and human caused external events considered in the process hazard analysis include:
 earthquake, tornado, extreme severe weather, flood
 inadequate physical security devices (locks, lighting, fences) may lead to outside threats which
   may lead to an anhydrous ammonia leak
 lack of security awareness training for employees to help identify internal threats
 lack of workplace violence policy and/or procedures could lead to a potential anhydrous
   ammonia release
 anhydrous ammonia theft from equipment that is outside and not monitored
 a suspicious package is delivered with the intent to cause an anhydrous ammonia release
 a bomb threat that could cause an ammonia release

All recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by facility management. A priority list is developed, and target dates are set for the recommendations to reduce or eliminate hazards.

 Operating Procedures
Written procedures and policies are in place that establish how the refrigeration system is operated and maintained. Thrive Freeze Dry has developed standard operating procedures for the required operating phases such as the safe and normal operation and shutdown of the refrigeration system. The manufacturers OEM manual may be used for reference. The standard operating procedures are periodically reviewed to ensure they reflect the current operating practices and certified to such annually.

 Mechanical Integrity
Prevention is the primary reason regular and scheduled inspection, testing, and maintenance is performed on the Thrive Freeze Dry refrigeration system. The system shall follow manufacturer recommendatio

ns, industry RAGAGEP, and/or industry practice to help maintain the system. The facility utilizes a mix of authorized and trained personnel and outside contractors to perform routine and emergency maintenance on the system.

 Incident Investigation
Written procedures and forms are in place detailing how and when the facility must investigate releases. Thrive Freeze Dry investigates releases and near misses that could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia. Recommendations are addressed and corrected by facility management. Reports are kept for five years.

 Training
Thrive Freeze Dry certifies operators following completion of operator training and confirmation of the operator's ability to apply what they have learned. Refrigeration operators are given initial training on hazards of anhydrous ammonia, an overview of the Thrive Freeze Dry refrigeration system, and emergency operations to name a few. To ensure compliance with the procedures, refresher training is conducted as required. Where possible, training utilizes direct experience in the field to facilitate task understanding and address multiple learning methods.

 Employee Participation
Thrive Freeze Dry employees help to improve and maintain the prevention program in multiple ways. Refrigeration operators participate in the process hazard analysis by providing system expertise. Refrigeration operators help develop operating procedures as well as ensure they reflect the true operating instruction. This involvement encourages ownership of the prevention program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.
 
All Thrive Freeze Dry employees receive ammonia awareness training and their responsibilities within the Emergency Action Plan. Additionally, they have access to the complete RMP / PSM, the IIPP and more for review, comment, and input. Together these activities improve the overall safety of the employees, environment, and the surrounding community.

 Compliance Audit
The audit pr

ocess is a valuable tool to confirm Thrive Freeze Dry compliance with the RMP / PSM program and whether each of the elements in the prevention program has been implemented and properly documented. Thrive Freeze Dry has established a Management System to address any shortcomings which the audit may find. A priority list is developed, and target dates are set for any changes or corrections.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
This system is new and has not been in operation for 5 years. Facility personnel are aware of the regulations for reporting the facility's 5-year accident history.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Action Plan developed for this facility for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials, and other emergencies. Facility personnel shall coordinate with responding outside agencies. The facilities emergency action plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. Facility personnel will exchange data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency. In addition, Fire Department personnel should tour the facility frequently to get a better understanding of the processes and the facilities during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and or a chemical release. 

Currently, on-site personnel do not enter an atmospheric concentration of 25 ppm for anhydrous ammonia. Facility personnel will assist the refrigeration contractor and outside agencies in a plant advisory role for releases exceeding 25 ppm. The plan for all releases is the safety of the employees, isolating and keeping personnel out of the affected area, and internal notifications and external notifications where necessary. All personnel not trained to respond will evacuate to the meeting
areas and be accounted for.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Employees, community safety, the environment and product care are primary concerns at this facility. The initial PHA

study were conducted at Thrive Freeze Dry and the study team made recommendations for improved safety. Thrive Freeze Dry will respond to all suggested mitigation measures promptly. Thrive Freeze Dry has established completion schedules for proposed actions. Management responses and support will be consistent with Thrive Freeze Dry's commitment to safe and environmentally responsible operations.

Thrive Freeze Dry recognizes that the RMP/PSM is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operations at its facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as Thrive Freeze Dry continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. Thrive Freeze Dry will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements / modifications to the RMP/PSM, related attachments, and program elements will be incorporated consistent with Thrive Freeze Dry's internal review practices and will maintain the most current versions onsite. Thus, the most current version RMP/PSM and related documents and
elements maintained onsite may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to EPA and other regulatory agencies.

Refer to the master tracking log which will include scheduled improvements to reduce accidental releases either in process or planned for at this time.
